title.narrative: Collaborative Research Program under the USAID-ARS Participating Agency Service Agreement (PASA)

description.narrative: USDA-ARS scientists at El Reno, Oklahoma, and Temple, and Texas, Baylor University are developing methods for rapid assessment of long-term annual average sedimentation rates in reservoirs to provide data to calibrate the Soil and Water Assessment Tool (SWAT) hydrologic model. Such calibrated models can improve the utility for assessing management and policy alternatives for national ministries, municipalities, and NGOs. This work is being done in cooperation with Jomo Kenyatta University of Agricultural and Technology (JKUAT), ICRAF, and the Kenyan Ministry of Water and Irrigation.

person-name.narrative: Daniel Herche and Tyson Whitney; Ryan Boles

transaction.usg:treasury-account: Agricultural Research Service, Salaries and Expenses
Agricultural Research Service, Salaries and Expenses

title.narrative: NASA'S Project Nile: Distributed hydrological information for basin-wide water management

description.narrative: To develop and evaluate a decision support tool for water management in the Nile River basin, using a combination of water balance modeling and remote sensing of evapotranspiration.

person-name.narrative: Daniel Herche and Tyson Whitney; Ryan Boles

Science, National Aeronautics and Space Administration

title.narrative: African Swine Fever

description.narrative: African Swine Fever work in Uganda and Kenya; data collection is underway by our collaborators. WS extended the ongoing work in Uganda with professors at Makerere University. WS met with cooperators from both countries in Uganda to visit field sites and discuss progress of activities.

title.narrative: Defense Threat Reduction (DOD)

description.narrative: Regional Biosurveillance Workshop - Uganda. The general purpose of the Regional Bioengagement Workshop in East Africa was to provide a forum in which African partners and Department of Defense leaders, in coordination with other U.S. Government Departments and Organizations, discussed the importance of a regional approach to bioengagement and to identify possible engagement opportunities in the human- animal areas under the One Health approach

title.narrative: Faculty Exchange Program - Africa Veterinary Fellows

description.narrative: The Faculty Exchange Program enhances the teaching ability of agricultural educators from institutions of higher learning in developing countries. Participants come to the United States for one academic semester (4-5 months) to increase their knowledge of, and ability to teach, agricultural economics, marketing, business and law in a market-based economy.

title.narrative: Borlaug Fellowship Program - Regulatory Harmonization

description.narrative: The United States has an existing Trade and Investment Framework Agreement with Kenya. There are strong indicators that this TIFA could soon lead to a Free Trade Agreement, resulting in increased agricultural trade opportunities. This award seeks to address ongoing Kenyan food safety issues through a focus on animal health.
